title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. I can just send messages and give people a call."And Irsquom pretty fortunate where I live ndash everyonersquos very friendly.

title: mountain-bikers-told-ride-within-limits-lockdown
story: MOUNTAIN bikers have been issued with guidance during lockdown.Scottish Cyclinghas outlined a series of dos and donts following the Scottish Governments go-ahead for people to exercise more than once a day.There are four rules cyclists and mountain bikers must adhere to under the new SC guidelines:Only ride from your home ndash it is not essential travel to go mountain biking or cycling and you may face enquiries from the policeyou are stopped en route or ing from a ride. All Forestry and Land Scotland car parks and trails, including the stanes sites, remain closedDo not go far ndash whilst you can go exercise for longer, we recommend riding close to where you live and not into remote areas ndash think more smaller loops rather than one longer remote rideRide well within your limits ndash only ride on trails that are that you are very confident you will be able to ride safely and within your competency. It is highly unlikely that mountain rescue are back to full operations ndash consider the fact that a full rescue may not be possible and may take longer to get to youOnly cycle with members of your own household - keep a safe distance when passing other cyclists or pedestrians.Mountain biking trails such as the stanes at Glentress, Peebles, and Innerleithen are closed until further notice to restrict travel to the trails and for safety as they are not being maintained as they were before lockdown.However, walking trails owned by Forestry and Land Scotland are open to members of the public who can access them without using transport.

title: borders-golfers-allowed-play-says-msp
story: BORDERS golfers and anglers should be allowed toto action, according to Rachael Hamilton.The Conservative MSP says she has written to the Scottish Government in a bid to get restrictions lted on outdoor activities.Mrs Hamilton said shooting and angling are among the activities which make an "immense contribution" to the rural economy.She said: "Outdoor sports, such as golfing, hiking and fishing, could take place with the necessary social distancing measures and it would not jeopardise the governmentrsquos efforts in tackling this pandemic."Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced last week that residents in England canto certain outdoor pursuits, including tennis and golf.But the Scottish Government has decided to retain the stay at home message, while now allowing people to exercise more than once a day.Mrs Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, says she has written to the Scottish cabinet secretary for rural economy and tourism, Fergus EwingMrs Hamilton, the shadow secretary, said: "We currently have an extraordinary situation in my constituency, around Coldstream, where people can happily fish in the English half of the River Tweed, whilst anglers in Scotland can only watch on from the Scottish side, where fishing is still not permitted at this time."By their nature, outdoor-based sports see participants spread out, whether over a hillside, across an open space or along a river."In the Borders and across rural Scotland, the angling and shooting industry needs to have clarity so it can plan for the new season."I urge the Scottish Government to rethink its restrictions, given the nature of these sports, and the immense contribution they make to our rural economy."

title: nicola-sturgeon-pledges-help-selkirk-ovo-workers
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has addressed the Scottish Parliament about the closure of a Borders office employing  workers.As reported yesterday, OVO Energy has revealed it will close its Selkirk site.At Holyrood today , Ms Sturgeon said: "I deeply regret the announcement from OVO Energy, which has a huge impact in Selkirk."OVO has declined to state how many jobs losses are likely in the Borders, with employees being invited to apply for voluntary redundancy first.The First Ministers comments came after a question from Borders MSP Rachael Hamilton, a Conservative member.Mrs Hamilton said: "These job losses are devastating for a fragile rural economy like the Scottish Borders and the young people, in particular, will be affected acutely."She added: "Can I ask the First Minister what the Scottish Governments response is to these job losses "And in the pandemic lockdown, will the PACE [redundancy] services be operating as normal to support these devastating job losses "In reply, Ms Sturgeon said: "We will, through Scottish Enterprise, continue to engage with this company [OVO] ndash and any company in a similar situation ndash to considerthere are any actions we can take to prevent or mitigate redundancies and well also make sure that PACE [redundancy support] is operational."

title: mcdonalds-glasgow-snubbed-list-drive-thrus-reopening
story: SCOTLANDis absent from the list ofMcDonalds restaurants re-opening their drive-thru lines - but theres a specic reason why.The fast-food giant announcedthat the drive-thru lanes at  locations across the UK and Republic of Ireland will open.It comes after McDonalds opened  of its restaurants in the South East of England exactly a week ago for delivery only, through Uber Eats.This new list also includes five new delivery-only locations which will reopen.But McDonalds restaurants in Scotlandhave been snubbed on all accounts.The list mainly includes restaurants based in the south and east of England, such as places like Ipswich and Peterborough.The sites opened from am on Wednesday and are offering a limited menu with orders capped at pound per car, the fast-food chain said.We are reopening  Drive Thru lanes across the UK and ROI. These Drive Thru pilot restaurants were all chosen as they are close to one of our distribution centres as we continue to prepare our supply chain for reopening. pic HqvctFokmdash McDonalds UKMay , Contactless payment is also being encouraged.McDonalds says the reasoning behind selecting the  stores is because they are all close to one of the companys distribution centres.A McDonalds spokesperson said: "Today we are reopening  drive-thru lanes at restaurants across the South East of England and in Dublin as we continue to test our plans for reopening."Our teams are still adjusting to the new procedures weve introduced to enable safe working and social distancing, so things might take a little longer."We expect a high demand across all locations."We are working closely with local authorities and we may determine that it is necessary to close our drive-thru lanesqueues cause disruption or put our employees or customers at risk."Staff will be temperature checked before each sht and the number of workers on each site will be reduced to ensure social distancing.Perspex screens are installed at all drive-thruwindows and staff will be given protective equipment.McDonalds is planning to open drive-thrus at all its stores across the UK and the Republic of Ireland by early June.The McDonalds spokespeson said: "Thank you for your continued patience as we slowly but safely reopen our restaurants."

title: six-things-need-know-sturgeon-confirms-lockdown-easing-next-week
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has set out a four-phase plan for Scotland to ease its way out of coronavirus lockdown.Phase  of the plan will begin from a week today, May .More outdoor activity, meeting other households and plans for the reopening of schools were among the topics discussed.Speaking to the Scottish Parliament, the First Minister said:ldquoI hope they will bring some improvement to peoplersquos wellbeing and quality of le, start to get our economy moving again, and start to steer us safely towards a new normality.ldquoItrsquos important to stress, though, that while the permitted reasons to be out of your house will increase, the default message during phase one will remain lsquoStay at home as much as possible.Six things you need to know from the announcement:Meeting family and friends:The First Minister confirmed today that as of May , your household will nowbe able to meet up with another household outdoors.This will need to be in small groups, including in gardens, but with social distancing required at all times.Under phase , you will not allowed to meet other households indoors - this will come in phase .Sports and outdoor activityThe latest easing of restrictions mean as of May  more outdoor activity will be permitted.This includes sunbathing or sitting in the park, as long as social distancing is maintained.Unrestricted outdoor exercise will continue, with non-contact sport such as golf, hiking, canoeing, outdoor swimming, fishing and bowls all back on the table.ShoppingDrive-thru outlets will be gradually re-opened under the new plans.Garden centres and plant nurseries can also reopen with physical distancing.However cafes should not open at this stage - except for takeaway.SchoolsSchool staff are toto the classrooms from May  - with Nicola Sturgeon confirming all schools in Scotland will reopen from August .The reopening of schools will be ablended model of in-school and at-home learning.From next week, child-minding services can reopen.Transition support will be available for children starting P and S as of next week.WorkAs we move into Phase , remote working remains the "default position" for those who can.For those who have to travel to work, a employers are encouraged to use staggered start times and flexible working.Nicola Sturgeon says she is encouraging employers to lookat the possibility of a -day week as we begin to look at dferent working patterns due to parenting restrictions with the eventual phased reopening of schools.Construction work can also begin to restartas of May .The Scottish Government is also preparing for the safe re-openinbg of the housing market.Pubs RestaurantsUnder the current guidance, pubs and restaurants will not be able to reopen next week.As of phase , which is an unknown date as yet, pubs and restaurants can open their outdoor spaces with physical distancing and increased hygeine routines.Only when we reach phase  will pubs be allowed to open their indoor spaces.View the route map in full:Note:Dates for phases - have not yet been set, as the virus "is and will remain unpredictable", accordingto the First Minister.

title: schoolboy-runs-50-miles-50-days-salvation-army
story: A BORDERS schoolboy has run  miles in  days to support homeless people.Robert Horton, nine, launched a fundraising challenge to help the Salvation Army after seeing a distressing news report.The St Ronans Primary School pupil has now completed his task ndash much to his fathers delight.Stephen Horton, of Innerleithen, said: "He hasnrsquot grumbled about it once ndash hersquos even been out in the wind and rain."Robert, a member of the Leithenburn Runners, came up with his project after learning about the struggle faced by homeless people.He said: "I felt sad that they had no food and had nowhere to stay and thought someone should help."Originally, Robert had planned to run every day for a month, but he decided to add an extra  days.During the challenge, he told this newspaper he was "tired", but added: "I will finish."Robert has raised more than pound so far, smashing his original target of pound.Mr Horton said he was "very proud" of his sons athletic achievement.The advanced nurse practitioner said: "I was sure that, physically, he was able."Hes in Leithenburn Runners and is doing pretty well."He runs everywhere, even bits of Lee Pen."But to stick at it for  days is excellent."Mr Horton and his we Lynsey were both able to join Robert on some of his runs.Robert has not been to school since March  due to the coronavirus outbreak.He said: "I miss all my friends from school and some of the clubs."Mr Horton added: "As a family its been challenging."As Im still at work, Lynsey has had to do the home-schooling."I think now we are starting to get used to the routine a bit better."But its fair to say the children miss seeing their friends ndash but WhatsApp and FaceTime have helped that in some way."Its hard for everyone not seeing their family."To donate to Roberts fundraiser, you can visit this website.

title: glasgow-parents-need-know-school-reopen-date-confirmed
story: NICOLA Sturgeonyesterdayconfirmedpupils from all of Scotlands schools are set toto classrooms inAugust.The First Minister revealed this will be a "blended" approach, far from normality for our nations youngsters, as part of a four-phase plan to ease the lockdown.But even this is reliant on two key factors -the scientic andmedical advice confirms it can be done in a way that will not disrupt efforts to control the virus andthere is sufficient PPE and other hygiene measures in place.Following Ms Sturgeons announcement in parliament, the Scottish Government published its strategic framework for the re-opening of schools.Here, well detailwhat parents need to know ahead of their childsto the classroom.When will schools re-open Schools in Scotland are set to re-open on August .This is earlier than planned for some schools - but the universal approach is being advised by the Scottish Government.Teachers are set toto the classroom by June to plan and prepare for the new blended model of learning.Some pupils set to start P or S may also receive some in-school experience in late June, to help ensure they are supported to make the next steps in their education.Critical childcare will continue until August to ensure the ongoing provision for key worker and vulnerable children.How will the blended model work Under this approach, children will have a mixture of in-school and in-home learning.According to the framework, this is reliant on consistent and easy-to-use in-home materials which are "intended to support and complement, but not replicate" in-school learning.To help disadvantaged pupils, a further poundm was announced to provide laptops and other technology for the home learning.However the document notes: "No matter how well planned in-home learning is, it is not the same as having effective learning and teaching within the school environment, led by teachers."The blended model will be kept under constant review.How will pupils social distance For the first phase of re-opening, schools are being asked to assess the maximum numbers they can accommodate, with guidance including:Pupils being taught in smaller groupsThese groups will not be mixed, where practicableSeating positions will be re-organised to allow for m gaps between pupilsOutdoor space will be used moreThere will be staggered arrival and departure times, so parents will avoid congregating in playground areasBreaks will be staggered by class to avoid contact from dferent classesTeachers, rather than pupils, will move around classrooms where possibleThere will be enhanced hygiene practices across all schools, including additional cleaning,params: .pushExpanding the learning estateLocal authorities are being advised to look for ways they can maximise the capacity for pupils to benefit from in-school learning as much as possible.One such way they are doing this is through expanding the learning estate.This would mean seeingclassrooms could be made fromoutdoor space,libraries, community halls, leisure centres and conference centres.It might also include taking short-term leases of vacant business accommodation.Who will be prioritised for in-school learning As set out above, there is likely going to be a finite number of daily places for in-school learning.As a result, to support NHS capacity and other essential work, a priority will be given to the children of keyworkers - but this is only in circumstances where absolutely necessary with no other option for childcare within that household.The remaining allocation is to be distributed across all year groups to ensure every pupils benefits from in-school learning where possible, according to the framework.Local authorities are being advices to use their knowledge of local circumstances to prioritise any groups where need is greatest.Speaking in the Scottish Parliament on Thursday, the First Minister said: ldquoThese arrangements will not represent a completeto normality by August.ldquoBut we judge them to be the most sensible approach we can plan for at this stage.Later in the session, the First Minister said the Scottish Government wants to ensure pupils will be back at school ldquoin a way that allows them to be children.She added: ldquoNone of us relish the prospect of seeing kids, particularly young kids, socially distancing or be as aware of these risks as we will undoubtedly have to require them to be.ldquoTrying to get, for children in particular, as much normality as possible in the school environment is really important.ldquoWe shouldnrsquot underestimate the challenges of that but it is absolutely central to all of this careful planning that is underway.

title: can-pubs-reopen-glasgow-plan-ease-lockdown-revealed
story: THE Scottish Government yesterday set out a route-map showing plans to ease out of the coronavirus lockdown.The four-phase plan will begin as of next week, with a number of measures being relaxed on May .More outdoor activity including sportsmeeting other households and the re-opening of recycling centres are among those being re-introduced at what is being described as Phase .But these areentirely dependent on dramatically reducing coronavirusin the country and successfully implementing a ldquoTest and Protect strategy.But what about pubs For those of us hankering for a leisurely drink in our local, the subject of ing to Scotlands pubs has been addressed in the route map.Current lockdown restrictions mean pubs and restaurants have been forced to close.The measures introduced yesterday also reveal that pubs will be forced to remain closed during Phase  - meaning they will notbe open on May .What about beer gardens Much of the new data being discussed by Scottish Government officials is around the potential for greater outdoor activity - which can be seen around plans for easing exercise restrictions.As such, the re-opening of pubs will begin with beer gardens.Under the plans, pubs and restaurants with outdoor spaces can reopen in Phase  - the exact date of which is not yet clear.This will be done provided social distancing is met and there are increased hygiene measures.So, when can I get inside a pub The route-map suggests that pubs can open their indoor spaces from Phase  in the four-phased plan.This will again only be done with physical distancing indoors and increase hygiene routines.Finally, by Phase , all pubs will be open as normal - with improved public health advice.

title: party-people-borders-invited-zoom-disco
story: BORDERERS desperate for a party after spending weeks in lockdown are being invited to throw on their gladrags and dancing shoes ndash and hit the living room for a night in.Mental health campaigner Emma Smith, of Peebles, is organising a virtual disco through Zoom.She said: ldquoI wanted to offer something that people could do from the comfort of their own homes, bringing the community together and giving them a welcome distraction from everything thatrsquos going on right now.Emma already has two successful charity events under her belt, having arranged for local singer-songwriter Tommy Ashby to headline gigs. A total of pound, went to the Scottish Association for Mental Health .Now, however, Emma is inviting people from Tweeddale and beyond to join a virtual dance party.She has teamed up with Silent Adventures to schedule an event for May  called lsquoThe Sessions in aid of SAMH disco In-Furloughrsquo.ldquoAlthough this is something we hadnrsquot planned for initially, the virtual format means we can bring even more people together, so I guess every cloud has a silver lining, said Emma."No matter where peoplersquos loved ones are in the world, or who they are isolating with, as long as they have Zoom they can get involved.Mental health is a cause which is ldquoreally close to Emmarsquos heart, she said, adding: ldquoMy hope is that by raising awareness through our events, and trying to get the message out there that it is OK not to be OK, it will help take the stigma away from something that affects so many people every single day.To take part in the event, which sees profits going to SAMH, Emma says you must register by sending an email to thesessions@hotmail

title: watch-council-meeting-living-room
story: BORDERS residents can tune into a live council meeting on the internet next week.Scottish Borders Councilis hosting a meeting of its Local Review Body on Mondayusing video-conferencing technology.It will be the second meeting organised over Microsoft Teams ndash but the first open to the public.Members of the public will not be allowed to ask questions, however, just as would be the case in physical meetings.The council says the Local Review Body meeting on June  will also be available to the public.The Local Review Body hears appeals against planning permission rejections.SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: ldquoThis is an important next step in the council being able to take decisions with absolute transparency while continuing to adhere to guidance on public meetings and social distancing.ldquoWe will continue to review how these initial online meetings operate prior to confirmation of a calendar for future council meetings involving greater numbers of councillors, council officers and agenda items.To access the councils online meetings, you can visit this website.

title: borders-house-prices-rise-2-5
story: HOMEOWNERS in the Borders have seen their houses become pricier during the coronavirus pandemic, statistics show.Registers of Scotlandhas published figures showing houseprice changes up to March.Between February and March, Borders prices rose by an average of . per cent, with the average price pound,.Across Scotland, the average price change was a . per cent rise, while the UK average saw a . per cent fall.Borders residents have also witnessed Scotlandrsquos greatest annual growth, with property prices rising . per cent in the last  months, compared with a Scottish average rise of . per cent.The average sale price in the Borders has grown by pound, in the last year.In March, the average property price in Scotland was pound,, while the UK average was pound,.An RoS spokesperson said: ldquoStatistics for March  will be affected by measures taken to tackle coronavirus ."The Scottish Government has issued guidance to delay moving home wherever possible."Fewer sales were completed this March compared with previous years, the spokesperson said.The final week of the month - when the UK entered lockdown - was ldquoparticularly affected, said the spokesperson.They added: ldquoThe effect of coronavirus on house price statistics from RoS will be able to be seen more conclusively in April  data due to be published on  June .

title: galashiels-photographers-adapting-lockdown
story: A GALASHIELS couple have seen their photography business badly hurt by coronavirus ndash but now they are taking their work to family doorsteps.Rose Ellis and her fianceacute Julien Borghino had to think quickly when client cancellations poured in following the arrival of COVID-.Now, adapting to lockdown restrictions, the pair have launched lsquodoorstep photographyrsquo sessions where they take portraits from outside peoplersquos homes.ldquoWersquore hoping it will be a chance for us to start taking pictures of people again, said Rose, , a Heriot-Watt University fashion graduate.Before the virus outbreak, Rose and Julienrsquos production company was kept busy by clients in the textiles industry.But the pair also offered photo shoots to tourists visiting Edinburgh, with the expectation that this summer would bring another packed calendar.While the fashion-related jobs have been buffeted by coronavirus, the impact on the tourist work has been far greater, according to Rose.ldquoAs soon as travel restrictions were introduced, visits were cancelled and then we lost our income for the rest of the summer ndash so that was pretty daunting, said Rose.She and Julien ndash who met on a fashion shoot in  ndash had enjoyed early success with the tourist market, offering an Airbnb Experience in Edinburgh for the past  months.Visitors from ldquoall over the globe have been snapped in the capital, said Rose, with some opting for the lsquofamilyrsquo package and others choosing the lsquocouplesrsquo experience.ldquoWersquove had a lot of people from America, a lot from countries in Europe ndash people from all over, really, which is whatrsquos so fantastic about that part of our job, said Rose.ldquoThis [coronavirus] has really hit us hard because with no tourists, there is nothing for us to do.Yet Rose said inspiration struck when a friend told them about a Glasgow-based photographer taking pictures outside peoplersquos front doors.Taking the idea and running with it, Rose and Julien began their own venture in the Borders this month.Focusing on Galashiels and places within a -mile radius, the couple are visiting homes to conduct -minutes shoots.ldquoItrsquos a no-contact session and only one of us will be carrying out the shoot, said Rose.ldquoWersquoll be using a telephoto lens which means we can be at a great distance but still take really nice pictures and really nice portraits.After each session, the client is sent a link to a website from where they can download between five and  photos, explained Rose.ldquoWe would love for it to be successful ndash we would love people to embrace the opportunity, she said.ldquoWersquove heard of photographers down south who are offering this service for free but at the end of the day, this is our jobs ndash this is our living."Rose and Julien had been due to get married in September, but they have postponed it because of uncertainty over coronavirus.

title: borders-pupils-officially-experts-greggs
story: BORDERS pupils have reached the final of a national competition ndash by showing off their knowledge of Greggs.The Growing Future Assets Challenge invites girls at Scottish schools to pitch an investment idea to professionals.Three students from Eyemouth High School impressed judges after explaining why the popular bakery chain would make a sound investment choice.S pupils Kate Harwood, Susie Ward and Jessica Isgate have been hailed for their research skills and presentation abilities.Eyemouth teacher Sarah Martin said: ldquoI am so proud of the efforts of this team to make it to the national finals."They all bring a certain flair to proceedings, alongside astute business brains."Their collaboration when having to work together during the current crisis shows a key business skill ndash resilience ndash and I look forward to seeing how they get on in the finals.Judges selected four teams to take part in the final, which will be held over Zoom on June  and .Each member of the winning team will receive pound, as well as pound, for their school.Greggs customer and marketing director Hannah Squirrell said the company was "delighted" to have been chosen by Kate, Susie and Jessica.Ms Squirrel added: "We are so impressed with their research and presentation skills, especially in the way they have adapted this to be purely digital during these times."We wish them every success in the online final.Deputy First Minister John Swinney said: ldquoThe Future Asset Competition is an exciting opportunity for girls across the country to access professional information and advice about careers in investment, a sector where women are under-represented."The process offers competitors the opportunity to enhance and develop their employability, financial, data analysis and presentation skills in a creative and real-le context, and I wish all those taking part this year the best of luck.

title: melrose-hotel-shuts-due-covid-19
story: A MELROSE hotel has closed because its owner went into administration.The Waverley Castle Hotel, on Waverley Road, stopped trading on May  following Specialist Leisure Group Limitedrsquoscollapse into administration.All bookings have been cancelled and employees are being contacted by the administrator, according to SLG.The hotel operated under the Bay Hotels brand, one of several run by SLG.A statement on SLGrsquos website reads: ldquoThe Specialist Leisure Group entered Administration on  May .ldquoAll tours, cruises, holidays and hotel breaks booked with the Specialist Leisure Group have been cancelled and will not be rescheduled.ldquoThe Specialist Leisure Group operated several businesses that sold holidays and other travel arrangements... which have all ceased to trade, due to the impact of COVID-.ldquoAll hotels trading as Bay Hotels, Coast  Country Hotels and Country Living Hotels will not reopen.

title: selkirk-rugby-players-bid-clean-town
story: HAVING just completed a sponsored charity project that raised almost pound, in under a fortnight for the townrsquos foodbank, Selkirk Rugby Clubrsquos players arenrsquot letting the grass grow under their feet.This week members of the clubrsquos playing squad have embarked on yet another lsquochallengersquo to support the local community ndash litter collection.The idea came from former st XV skipper Ross Nixon, and comes in the wake of a similar venture undertaken by Glasgow Warriorsrsquo professional players.ldquoWhen yoursquore walking in and around Selkirk, you canrsquot help noticing pieces of litter that have been left lying around, often when proper bins arenrsquot that far away, said Nixon.ldquoI thought it would be a good idea for Selkirk players to take a bin bag with them when they head out to take their daily exercise, picking up any litter they see next to paths or along roadside verges.ldquoWersquore lucky in Selkirk to have such unspoilt countryside to exercise in, so itrsquos a shame to see it spoiled by discarded empty bottles, food wrappers and general rubbish.ldquoI kicked off the campaign by nominating three members of our players ndash Aaron McColm, Ewan MacDougall and Liam Cassidy ndash to collect litter on their walks.ldquoEach of this trio will then challenge a further three players to collect litter, and in turn these three will nominate other team-mates, and so on.The project has the backing of Selkirk head coach Scott Wight.He said: ldquoItrsquos another way the club can put something back into the local community, though this time therersquos no sponsorship involved.ldquoItrsquos looking asitrsquos going to be a wee while before any rugby is going to be played, so this latest effort not only helps keep the players in touch with each other, itrsquos also providing a useful service for the Selkirk community.Meanwhile, Selkirk Rugby Club is to stage its annual Players Presentation Night on Fridayndash although this yearrsquos event will be a lsquovirtualrsquo get-together.The plan is for the clubrsquos coaches, players and rugby officials to be digitally linked via Zoom, with Selkirk head coach Scott Wight taking charge of proceedings.ldquoThe idea is to try and stick as closely as possible to the format normally used at the clubrsquos annual presentation nights, said Wight.ldquoA total of nine trophies are up for grabs, and the name of each award winner will be announced separately on the video link, followed by film footage, or photos, of that player in a match situation.ldquoShort addresses will be given by, among others, the clubrsquos chairman and its director of rugby, as well as recaps of the st and lsquoArsquo XVsrsquo seasons by the sidesrsquo respective team managers."It should be a fun evening!

title: get-free-delivery-border-telegraph-6-weeks
story: READERS of the Border can now get free home delivery for six weeks.Anyone wishing to get their paper delivered through their letter box at no extra cost can call   .Once you have rung up, you will speak to a member of our home delivery team, who will take your details securely over the phone.This limited-time offer might be particularly useful for any elderly relatives, neighbours of friends.Dont forget, however, that you can also sign up to our websitefor pound a week ndash giving you unlimited access to all of our journalism.We have introduced the subscription model because our revenues have been hit by coronavirus.For those of you who do not wish to support us through a digital subscription, a certain amount of content will still be free to read.

title: four-day-working-week-among-new-normal-glasgow-coronavirus-lockdown
story: NICOLA Sturgeon says bosses in Scotland should consider rolling out a four-day working week after the coronavirus lockdown.The First Minister told the Scottish Parliament it is important the country does not slip into "old and bad ways of doing things.She said: ldquoThings like a four-day week are no longer things that we should just be talking about, these are things we should be encouraging employers to look at embracing, and there are a whole range of things that fall into that category.Ms Sturgeons comments came afterScottish Labour leader Richard Leonard asked howthe economy would look following the virus crisis.From August, pupils will undertake aldquoblended method of schooling ndash made up of in-school and at home learning ndash which means employers are expected to consider dferent working practices.What is a four-day working week Quite simply, it is as the name suggests.Instead of working five days, you will be working four ndash but rather than compressing the usual hours, an employee has reduced hours.For example, instead of working .hours, they will work  hours over the four days.Many have suggested the arrangement enables a better work le balance for employees and results in greater productivity when working.What do people who already run it say A Glasgow-based charity that moved to a four-day week in  said it had led to many benefits.Advice Direct Scotland, which advises people on consumer, benefits and debts issues, gave their staff fewer working hours while maintaining the same wages.Chief executive Andrew Bartlet said it had led to a better work-le balance for the organisation, consisting of around  employees and  volunteers.He said: ldquoIn , we became one of the first major organisations in Scotland to introduce a four-day working week, recognising the positive dference this would make.ldquoAbsenteeism has reduced and productivity has increased as a result.ldquoPrior to lockdown, this created a more positive atmosphere in the office, with staff encouraged to share stories about the activities they enjoyed on their extra day off.ldquoAs we move towards easing lockdown, we would certainly recommend a four-day working week to Scottish businesses.Could it be implemented in Scotland or the UK The concept has been gaining traction in recent years and it comes as no surprise that it is being suggested in a bid to restore the countryrsquos economy.It comes as Chancellor Rishi Sunak has warned the UK is facing a ldquosevere recession, the likes of which we have never seen as a result of the coronavirus crisis.Several firms across the country, as highlighted above, already voluntarily operate the scheme, but it is yet to be formally enshrined in law.But the recent move by Ms Sturgeon to encourage the four-day working week could go a long way to the lsquonew normalrsquo we are to expect once lockdown ends.

title: can-go-summer-holiday-airlines-running
story: As lockdown continues across the country, the idea of a summer holiday might be the last thing onpeoples minds.But as the weather continues to improve, and measures begin to ease, itrsquos understandable that some Brits may be looking forward to a spot of quality time in the sun.And with the idea of some travel restrictions being reduced between certain countries, could a foreign holiday still be on the cards Here, wersquove pulled together the latest government advice and updates from airlines to help keep you informed.Can I travel abroad for a holiday Currently, British nationals are being urged not to take any non-essential foreign travel.Some countries, including the US, have travel restrictions in place which are limiting or preventing foreign arrivals.And the UK Government is planning to introduce a -day quarantine period ldquoas soon as possible, meaning visitors and UK nationals ing home will have to self-isolate for two weeks once arriving here.However, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps has suggested that ldquoair bridges could be introduced.This would see an arrangement where travellers arriving in from countries with low coronavirus levels could be exempt from quarantine.For example, Greecersquos tourism industry hopes to once again be ldquoopen for business sometime in July ndash with their tourism minister Haris Theoharis calling on their country to be exempt from quarantine rules.What do the airlines say EasyjetEasyJet is to resume flights from  European airports from June .Flights will serve a number of UK airports including Glasgow, Edinburgh, Inverness, Gatwick, Bristol, Birmingham, Liverpool, Newcastle and Belfast.The only international route from the UK will be between Gatwick and Nice, France.New measures introduced, however, will mean passengers must wear masks and no food will be sold during flights.A spokeswoman said it is ldquointroducing new measures to help ensure safety and wellbeing, including enhanced aircraft cleaning and disinfection and requirement for passengers and crew to wear masks.JetJet and Jetholidays has announced plans to resume flights and holidays on July .A spokesman said: ldquoWe have said throughout that the sun will shine again and when it does, we will be there to take customers away on their well-deserved holidays.ldquoAs well as taking them away for their much-needed holidays, customers can be assured that we will be implementing measures, in consultation with the relevant authorities, to ensure the safety and well-being of everybody onboard.Destinations will include Alicante, Zante, Verona, Malaga and Madeira.Customers set to depart before this will be contacted by Jet, to discuss their options, including rebooking their holiday.TUITUI is planning to resume trips on June  to destinations including Albania, Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Germany and IcelandThe tour operator says the situation will be "continuously reviewed."A TUI spokeswoman said: ldquoWe understand that these are incredibly uncertain times and wersquore continually reviewing and updating our policies in line with government guidelines."Our holidays departing after  June  are currently due to operate as planned."Itrsquos also reassuring for customers to know that all of our package holidays are ATOL protected, so travellers can book their future holidays with confidence."If the holiday needs to be cancelled down the track, they will be offered the option to either receive a refund credit with a bonus incentive or a cash refund."We know our customers will want to travel again and we are excited and ready to take them on their holidays as soon as we are able to.RyanairRyanair says it plans to restore % of its flights from July .The airline is set to restart flying from most of its  bases across Europe ndash with destinations from the UK including Berlin, Prague, Venice, Malta and Marrakesh.Passengers and crew will be required to wear face coverings and pass temperature checks. No cash will be accepted on board.Passengers flying in July or August will have to complete a form detailing how long their visit will be and where they are staying. This will be provided to EU governments.,params: .pushRyanair chief executive Eddie Wilson said: ldquoIt is important for our customers and our people that weto some normal schedules from  July onwards.ldquoGovernments around Europe have implemented a four-month lockdown to limit the spread of the Covid- virus.ldquoAfter four months, it is time to get Europe flying again so we can reunite friends and families, allow people toto work and restart Europersquos tourism industry, which provides so many millions of jobs.BABritish Airways is planning a ldquomeaningfulto service in July ndash depending on restrictions being eased.A spokesman said: "These plans are highly uncertain and subject to the easing of lockdowns and travel restriction."Virgin AtlanticThe airline has said it wont resume flights until August "at the earliest" following the announcement of the -day quarantine for those entering the UK.A spokeswoman said: "The safety and security of our people and our customers is always our top priority and public health must come first."However, by introducing a mandatory  day self-isolation for every single traveller entering the UK, the governmentrsquos approach will prevent flights from resuming."We are continually reviewing our flying programme and with these restrictions, there simply wonrsquot be sufficient demand to resume passenger services before August at the earliest.ldquoWe know that as the Covid- crisis subsides, air travel will be a vital enabler of the UKrsquos economic recover.ldquoTherefore, we are calling for a multi-layered approach of carefully targeted public health and screening measures, which will allow for a successful and safe restart of international air travel for passengers and businesses.Can I travel in Scotland for a trip Under current Scottish Government restrictions, all holiday accommodation is closed.Many tourist hotspots are actively encouraging visitors to stay away to avoid the spread of the virus.And these measures will NOT change when we move into phase  of the four-part route map out of lockdown on Thursday, May .In fact,only in phase  - which is suspected to be in August by the earliest - will the Scottish Government allow for a "relaxation of restrictions on accommodation providers".

title: aldi-introduces-new-shopping-rule-avoid-massive-queues-keep-social-distancing
story: ALDI stores across Scotland have introduced a new system to control the number of customers going in and out of stores.In recent weeks, queues have been forming outside stores as new measures were introduced to stop the spread of the coronavirus.The retailer is now implementing an automatic traffic light system at entrances, which starts this week following a successful trial.Traffic lights will signal when customers can enter stores based on inidual store customer limits that are in line with two-metre social distancing rules.Richard Thornton, Communications Director at Aldi said: ldquoThe protection and safety of our customers and employees is our top priority and this new system is an accurate and effective way to allow us to control customer numbers in stores.ldquoThe systemrsquos trial was well received by our customers and we will be gradually rolling this new social distancing measure out nationwide from this week.NHS and blue light worker priority access remains in place.These workers are encouraged to go to the front of the queue and other customers will be asked to continue to respect this.The traffic light system will run alongside the current measures already in place at all Aldi stores to ensure social distancing.This includes protective screens at checkouts, distancing markers on shop floors, sanitisation stations for customers as well as signage to offer clear guidance on how to shop safely.Stores are also encouraging one customer per trolley where possible.

title: borders-mp-avoids-dominic-cummings-resignation-question
story: JOHN Lamont MP has failed to answer a direct question on whether Dominic Cummings should stand down.Mr Cummings, the Prime Ministers adviser, has been accused of breaking lockdown rules after he admitted driving  miles in late March.The Border asked Mr Lamont to comment on the controversy, going on to specically invite the Borders MP to say whether he believes Mr Cummings should resign.In a written response, the Conservative member for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk said: "Over the last few days, I have ensured that the views of those many constituents who have contacted me on this matter have been communicated directly to the government."I very much share the sense of frustration that has been expressed to me and it is essential the voices of local people are heard at the highest levels."For my own part, I have strictly observed the lockdown rules over the last nine weeks from my home in Coldstream, as I know the overwhelming majority of us are."That is the way we can make sure we all come through this together."On May , Mr Cummings gave a public statement at Downing Street in which he sought to explain his behaviour.He cited childcare issues as the reason for his long trip.

title: glasgow-weather-mini-heatwave-24c-weekend-lockdown-set-ease
story: SCOTLAND is set to enjoy a mini heatwave this week and into the weekend - just as parts of the lockdown are set to ease.Nicola Sturgeon is due to announce on Thursday whether or not the country can move into phase  of the route-map out of lockdown.If this is the case, Scots can sunbathe in parks beaches andmeet one other household outside or in gardens from Friday -whilemaintaining physical distance.Non-contact sport like golf and fishing can also be allowed.And forecasters are predicting sizzling temperatures across the country - just in time.In Glasgow, forecasters are predicting C on Friday, with C on Saturday and C on Sunday.Keeping in the west, Ayrshire is set to average around C across the three days .In Edinburgh, temperatures of around -C are forecast, with -C predicted for parts of Fe andaround C in the Borders.A Met Office statement reads: "A dry spell of weather with long bright or sunny spells."Becoming very warm with temperatures reaching the mid twenties Celsius."But despite the warm temperatures, the public are being warned over the "genuine danger" that coronavirus will begin to spread as the lockdown measures are eased.Over the next few days it looks set to be very warm in many places. Today and tomorrow the highest temperatures will be in the South East, but as the week goes on the peak of the warmth will transfer north and west #StayHomeSaveLives# StayAlert pic TYoSNMzyaRmdash Met OfficeMay , Speaking on Monday, the First Minister said that ldquoeven as we glimpse a possible end to some lockdown restrictions it is ldquomore important than ever to follow the measures that remain in place.ldquoAs we start to lt these restrictions there is a genuine danger that the virus will start to spread again a bit more quickly, she said.ldquoThe way in which we ensure that doesnrsquot happen ndash and that way in which we enable even more restrictions to be lted in future ndash is to continue to follow whatever public health guidance is in place at the time.

title: properly-test-eyesight-good-enough-drive
story: MOTORISTS have been urged to test their eyesight amid concerns many behind the wheel do not realise they are too shortsighted to drive.An awareness campaign by the DVLA in  has resurfaced calling on drivers to test whether they can see a number plate from  metres away.The ldquonumber plate test reflects the legal distance from which all motorists should be able to read a sign.Earlier this week, the Prime Ministers aideDominic Cummings said he tested his eyesight during lockdown by driving to Barnard Castle in County Durham.What is the legal limitfor sight A DVLA survey indicated that fewer than half of drivers knew that metreswas the legal limit for sight.Five car sis said to roughly match the distance and road users are being encouraged to use the measure to test their vision on passing signs.Anyone concerned about their vision should visit an optician or optometrist for an eye test, the DVLA said.Motoristsshould carry out the number plate test before drivingWyn Parry, the DVLArsquos senior doctor, said:ldquoThe number plate test is a simple and effective way for people to check their eyesight meets the required standards for driving.ldquoThe easiest and quickest way to do this is to work out what  metres looks like at the road side ndash this is typically about theof fivecars parked next to each other ndash and then test yourself on whether you can clearly read the number plate.,params: .pushldquoItrsquos an easy check to perform any time of day at the road side and takes just a couple of seconds.ldquoHaving good eyesight is essential for safe driving, so itrsquos really important for drivers to have regular eye tests.Eyesight can naturally deteriorate over time, he added, meaning those who have never needed glasses before could eventually require a pair.Top tips to check before driving for the first time in a whileFor those whose cars have been parked up for a few weeks, MoneySavingExpert has published several key points that drivers should check before setting off on essential journeys:Brakes:If yourhandbrake parking brake hasnt been released since you last drove, it may stay locked when you first release it. Drive off gently and it should free itself, though you might hear a loud clunk from one of the wheels. Apply the brakes when you first drive off toondash they may sound noisyrust has built up on the discs, but this should clear after you use them a few times.Fluids:Before starting the engine, check all fluid levels, including brake fluid, coolant, engine oil, power-steering fluid and screenwash.MOT:If your MOT expired on or after Monday,March , you DONT have to get your car tested for six monthsfrom the expiry date due to an extension granted because of the pandemic. If it expired before Monday, March , youll need to book an MOT as usual and shouldnt drive until youre taking your car for the test. Although test centres and garages have been allowed to stay open so you can do this, the Government says that at present you should only get your MOT doneyou need your car to be able to shop for bare necessities, for medical reasons or for work .Tyres:If youve not beenkeeping them inflated to the correct pressurewhile youve been off the road, check the pressure and inflate accordingly before you head out.Vehicle tax:Check your car is taxed oryou could face a fine of up to pound,. If you have declared it as being off the road by getting a Sorn , you will need to renew your vehicle tax. For full details, seepaying vehicle tax.Check nothings living under the bonnet:Before starting your car after a lay-up, the AA says you should pop the bonnet and make sure that nothing has nested in your engine and or chewed through any pipes or hoses.

Deaths per locationThe majority of coronavirus-linked deaths across Scotland in the week to May  were in care homes at %, down from % the previous week.The number of deaths in care homes also fell for a fourth week in a row, down by  in a week to .The NRS figures also show % of registered deaths involving coronavirus between May  and  were in hospitals, up from % the previous week, while % were at home or in non-institutional settings, down from % the week before.. title: nasa-spacex-rocket-launch-visible-glasgow-tonight--
story: PEOPLE across Scotland will be able to catch a glimpse of NASArsquos Space X rocket as it fires into the sky tonight.UPDATE: THE LAUNCH HAS BEEN POSTPONED UNTIL SATURDAYThe launch will be the first manned flight to take off from American soil since  ndash with the world watching eagerly to see how astronauts Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley fare on their journey to the International Space Station .And the fortunate weather forecasts means we should hopefully be able to view it above us.The SpaceX Falcon  rocket will lt off from the Kennedy Space Centre in Florida at around .pm EDT ndash around .pm UK time.The rocket should be visible over Scotland around  minutes later at around .-.pm.and Douglas Hurley" alt"Border : Astronauts Robert Behnkenand Douglas Hurley" class"editor-image"Astronauts Robert Behnkenand Douglas HurleyProvided there is not much cloud, some places in Scotland will be able to get some great views of the craft with the sky very light.MeteorWatch says the rocket will pass over the country from a westerly direction, heading east.It should be visible for three to four minutes, says the service.It adds: "As the Spacecraft passes over the UK, we may see just the one or a collection of objects looking like bright stars moving across the sky.ldquoThe sky will be fairly light for some especially for observers in places in the north such as Scotland.ldquoThe craft should be bright enough to follow once you catch a glimpse of it."#Nasa is streaming the launch live on Nasa TV, which is available to watch on YouTube at: https:www.youtube watch vAymrnzianf

title: nasa-cancels-rocket-launch-borders-seen
story: NASA has cancelled the launch of a rocket which would have been visible over skies in the Borders.The SpaceX Falcon  rocket had been scheduled to lt offfrom the Kennedy Space Centre in Florida at around .pmon May .But space chiefs have pulled the plug on the launch due to bad weather.NASA published a tweet at .pm ndash minutes before the planned lt-off ndash to noty the expectant world of its decision.The tweet reads: "We are not going to launch today."Due to the weather conditions, the launch is scrubbing."Our next opportunity will be Saturday, May  at :pm ET."Live #LaunchAmerica coverage will begin at am ET."

title: volunteers-plant-colourful-display-innerleithen
story: DESPITE St Ronans Border Games Week being cancelled this year, there will be a blooming marvellous display in the town reminding locals of their historic traditions.At a time when everyone is keeping their hands meticulously clean, volunteers from Bonnie Innerleithen and the Edible Garden were getting theirs dirty to plant the summer display in the flowerbeds at the top of Traquair Road.And the plants werenrsquot the only things that had to be spaced out ndash the green-fingered volunteers had to make sure they kept a safe social distance to adhere to government guidelines.Gordon Daly, Fiona Jack, Julie Waddell and Alex Smithson, along with her family, accomplished a great team effort to weed and place the huge number of plants for both beds.The plants ndash including white snapdragon, cosmos, gypsophila, blue nigella, salvia and Swan River daisies ndash will give a vibrant display of blue and white and will be a welcome reminder of the townrsquos festivities which were cancelled due to coronavirus.This seasons display has been sponsored by Innerleithens Ex Standard Bearers in association with both the community trust and community council.Grown by the children of St Ronans Primary School under the expert supervision of Alex Smithson, from The Edible Garden, the scene promises to be a wonderful splash of colour for the towns High Street.The Edible Garden has been established at St Ronans Primary School for more than five years.It works in partnership with the St Ronans Youth and Community Centre and received money from Scottish Borders CouncilsLocalities Bid Fund last year.The garden provides a venue for learning how to grow fruit and vegetables using organic methods and has a polytunnel, raised beds, and a fruit orchard.All pupils from the school participate in gardening activities, and families are welcomed at the weekly garden club when school is open.Volunteers from the wider community are an essential part of the team that helps gardener Alexandra Smithson maintain the garden.Secretary of Innerleithen Community Council Gordon Daly has been driving the project forward following cuts to seasonal planting displays by SBC.He said: ldquoWith the help of the schools eco committee of pupils we sowed a range of flower seeds that were germinated in classrooms."The young plants were potted up in the garden polytunnel before being planted out in the beds on the High Street."The flowers were chosen to celebrate the Games Week colours of blue and white and also to attract bees and pollinators throughout the summer.

title: fairy-godmothers-visiting-children-borders
story: FAIRY godmothers do exist ndash at least here in the Borders they do.The Scottish Fairy Godmothers is a Facebook page, set up by Borders residents, which offers comfort during lockdown ndash and gts surprises to members.Peebles member Zoe Falconer said: ldquoThe page is for people to have a chat with one another during these hard times."You can create an Amazon gt list and post this on the page and people gt you off this list.The group has now signed up nearly  members throughout the region.Zoe said: ldquoWe decided to make a wish list for the children and we are making up gt bags to deliver throughout June."It is funded by members of the page and all children who are nominated will receive a gt."We wanted to do something nice for youngsters ndash they have accepted all the changes in their lives due to this terrible virus and have adapted really well.With the help of her friend Kathleen Aitchison, Zoe will be delivering gts to more than  children in Peebles alone.Describing how the group has helped since lockdown began, Zoe said: ldquoYou can talk to people and donrsquot feel so alone ndash and itrsquos always nice to get a wee gt through your door.The Scottish Fairy Godmothers was set up by Galashiels resident Jade Nisbet alongside Danielle Johnston from Melrose.

title: coronavirus-test-trace-programme-work
story: New contact tracing systems which aim to contain the spread of coronavirus are being rolled out across England and Scotland on Thursday.But how do they work and what do people need to do ndash What do I have to doI am worried I have coronavirus If you begin showing coronavirus symptoms such as a fever, continuous cough or loss of smell or taste then you should self-isolate immediately for at least seven days and order a test.Anyone  in your household should also self-isolate for  days from when you began showing symptoms.You can order a test in England by calling  or going to NHS.UK coronavirus and in Scotland by calling   or visiting nhsinform.scot.vw,vw,px, px"ndash How do I get tested Once you request a test you will be asked to either attend a test site or carry out a test at home.The UK and Scottish governments are both aiming to provide results within  hours of taking a test.ndash What happensmy test comes back negative If your test is negative you and your household can come out of self-isolation.vw,vw,px, px"A person on the NHS coronavirus contact tracing app ndash Whatthe result shows I have coronavirus If your test comes back positive you and your household must complete your self-isolation periods.You will also be contacted by contact tracers and asked to provide details of people you have been in close contact with ndash defined in England as being within two metres for more than  minutes without protective equipment.In England, you will be asked to do this online through a secure website or called by one of the NHS contact tracers.ndash What happensI am told I have come into contact with someone with coronavirus In England,you have come into contact with someone who has tested positive for Covid- you will be contacted either by text or email and asked to login confidentially to the NHS Test and Trace website.vw,vw,px, px"If you are unable to do this online, a trained call handler will ring you and talk you through what you need to do.In both countries you will be told to isolate for  days from your last contact with the person with Covid-, evenyou do not have symptoms.Other members of your household do not need to isolateyou do not have symptoms.ndash WhatI develop symptoms after being in contact with someone who has tested positive If you develop symptoms, your household should immediately begin to self-isolate for  days and you should order a test.If it is positive, the test and trace process will begin again.vw,vw,px, px"A Covid- antibody testing kit moves along the factory line If you test negative you will still be asked to complete your -day isolation.ndash Why do people who do not have symptoms have to isolate for  days while people who have tested positive only do seven The NHS says you should still isolate for  days after being in contact with someone who has tested positive because it can take that long for any symptoms to develop.However, people who have tested positive should isolate for seven days or longertheir symptoms have not gone, it adds.ndash If I have to take time off work to isolate will I get any support Those self-isolating will be eligible for statutory sick pay, while those who are self-employed will be able to access cash grants.You might also be able to get support from your local council such as having food or medical supplies delivered, the Government said.In Scotlandyou need support you can call the National Assistance Helpline on   .ndash How will the system be enforced Initially the system will rely on you and everyone  acting responsibly and following the guidanceyou are told to isolate.Butthe system of voluntary compliance does not work, ministers will be able to bring in tougher measures which could see people potentially subjected to spot checks and finedthey are not following the rules.ndash WhatIrsquove already tested positive for Covid- and recovered ndash will I need to isolate againcontacted You must still isolate as instructed because it is not yet known whether having the disease in the past means you are now immune, or whether you can still act as a carrier who can infect others.ndash What has happened to the NHS contact tracing app A contact tracing app in is being trialled on the Isle of Wight but it has been delayed by several weeks.Leaders have not set a launch date.ndash What are the other parts of the UK doing Walesrsquos contact-tracing plan is set to go live on Monday, while a pilot contact-tracing programme began in Northern Ireland at the start of April and has been ramped up to a seven-day operation which will last for at least a year, health leaders there have said..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: How does the coronavirus Test and Trace programme work

title: scotlands-lockdown-eased-six-things-can-cant-phase-1-begins
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has today confirmed lockdown measures will be eased in Scotland.The First Minister said phase  of the four-phase plan will begin from tomorrow with some "careful but cautious changes" to protocol.Shethanked the Scottish public, saying the fact the changes could be made were down to compliance with lockdown measures.Ms Sturgeon said that a downward trend was ldquosustained and unmistakable.People will also now be allowed to sit and sunbathe in local parks.A legal limit will not be put on how far people will be allowed to travel for recreation but the First Minister said the ldquostrong advice of the Scottish Government was to stay within five miles.Nicola Sturgeon confirms Scotland will now move to Phase One of lting the coronavirus lockdown #Lockdown@NicolaSturgeonpic QvAApfJTmdash Ryan CapperauldMay , What can I do Meeting family and friends:The First Minister confirmed today that as of tomorrow, your household will nowbe able to meet up with another household outdoors.This will need to be in small groups - a maximum of eight.You can meet outdoors and in privategardens, but with social distancing required at all times.Under phase , you will not allowed to meet other households indoors - this will come in phase .The First Minister advised those wanting to have a BBQ with other households to bring their own food and avoid contact with others.Sports and outdoor activityThe easing of restrictions mean as of tomorrow, more outdoor activity will be permitted.This includes sunbathing or sitting in the park, as long as social distancing is maintained.Unrestricted outdoor exercise will continue, with non-contact sport such as golf, hiking, canoeing, outdoor swimming, fishing and bowls all back on the table.Shopping Fast FoodDrive-thru outlets will be allowed tore-open under the new plans.Garden centres and plant nurseries can also reopen with physical distancing.However cafes should not open at this stage - except for takeaway.SchoolsSchool staff are toto the classrooms from Monday - with Nicola Sturgeon confirming all schools in Scotland will reopen from August .The reopening of schools will be ablended model of in-school and at-home learning.From next week, child-minding services can reopen.Transition support will be available for children starting P and S as of next week.WorkAs we move into Phase , remote working remains the "default position" for those who can.For those who have to travel to work, a employers are encouraged to use staggered start times and flexible working.Most outdoor work can begin from tomorrow, with construction work able toresume site preparation.,params: .pushRecycling CentresRecycling centres in Scotland will be allowed to open.What cant I do Pubs RestaurantsUnder the current guidance, pubs and restaurants will not be able to reopen next week.As of phase , which is an unknown date as yet, pubs and restaurants can open their outdoor spaces with physical distancing and increased hygeine routines.Only when we reach phase  will pubs be allowed to open their indoor spaces.RetailersNon-essential shops like fashion retailers will be asked to remain closed at this time.Other householdsYou still cannot enter other households.This means when visiting other gardens, the First Minister encouraged common sense - adding not to travel too far in case you need to use the toilet.Public TransportPublic transport remains limited for essential journeys only.You should not take public transport for exercise or to visit friends outdoors.Visiting beauty spotsThe advice remains on not visiting these areas.The First Minister said: ldquoWe simply donrsquot want, in this phase, large numbers of people at tourist hotspots or beauty spots.ldquoCrowds of people, eventheyrsquore trying to social distance, bring more risk than we judge is acceptable at this point.Contact sports Contact sports, like football and rugby, remain off limits during the current review.Only non-contact sports where physical distancing can be remained are allowed during the new protocol.

title: pharmaceutical-giants-feel-responsibility-ensure-everyone-vaccine
story: Pharmaceutical giants feel a ldquodeep responsibility to make sure no one gets left behind when it comes to accessing a coronavirus vaccine, an industry leader has said.Companies such as AstraZeneca, GlaxoSmithKline , Johnson and Johnson, and Pfizer are working with researchers across the world to ensure a vaccine can be manufactured at speed once one becomes available.But questions have been raised about who will get access to the doses, and when.Thomas Cueni, director general of the International Federation of Pharmaceutical Manufacturers and Associationssaid it was widely accepted that once a successful Covid- vaccine is created it will not be available in sufficient quantities from the beginning.He added: ldquoI think I sense a deep responsibility among the industry that we need to be careful about no one left behind.ldquoWhen we look at the scaling-up needs, we do know we will not have sufficient quantities, as from day one, even with the best of efforts.ldquoWe need to be careful that vaccines need to be safe and effective, and they need to be scalable.Over the past  years, the biopharmaceutical industry has been helping @Gavisucceed and innovate #VaccinesWork. Our common goal is to protect the most valuable resource on earth: its children.More on #GenerationGavi: https:t.co YQxFMAtgepic EEbcYtvuPmdash IFPMAMay , He added: ldquoThe challenge is daunting ndash itrsquos just two days ago that I saw a chart which predicted we may need  billion dosages when you do a population-based study.Mr Cueni also said: ldquoIt is important that healthcare workers, irrespective of where they are, get vaccinated first and it is important that we do have this strong sense of solidarity.Dr Albert Bourla, chairman and chief executive of Pfizer, said it is also important to prepare for a potential second wave of coronavirus in the autumn.He added: ldquoTo be frank, the challenges will be that every national government would like to get a vaccine for them.ldquoAnd I think, although there are discussions at WHOthe reality is that governments will try to exercise all the leverage that they have to be among the first to receive vaccines and ndash us ndash Irsquom afraid wersquoll be caught in the middle.He continued: ldquoSo Irsquom thinking very carefully what would be the best way to make sure that everybody will get the fair share of supplies that exist as quickly as possible.ldquoAnd that in this fairness, we will not forget the unprivileged countries that commercially play very little role,any, but from the human perspective they all have equal rights.Speaking at an IFPMA media briefing about how more doses could be produced, Dr Bourla explained: ldquoTypically we are producing vaccines in single dose vials.ldquoWe are also exploring with governments right now,it would be more convenientthere are five dose vials, or  dose vials.ldquoBecausewe can find out that this could be a presentation that is acceptable and practical, given the pandemic nature, I think we can resolve a signicant part of the bottleneck in manufacturing.GSK chief executive officer, Emma Walmsley, said it is widely recognised that there is a global need, and that multiple candidates need to be supported in order to get to scale as fast as possible, because the ldquobest way to guarantee access is to have the volume available.At the briefing, AstraZeneca, GSK, Johnson and Johnson, and Pfizer said they would supply Covid- vaccines on a no-profit basis as long as the pandemic lasts.Asked when he thought a vaccine may be available, Pascal Soriot, executive director and chief executive officer at AstraZeneca, which is working to manufacture the University of Oxford vaccine candidate, said ldquobefore the end of the year.He said: ldquoHopefully several before the end of this year, and the capacity will continue increasing next year ndashthose vaccines are successful ndash both in terms of manufacturing capacity but also additional vaccines coming available..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Pharmaceutical giants feel  uresponsibility u to ensure everyone has vaccine

title: paddy-power-owner-taps-investors-cash-online-gaming-revenues-jump
story: Paddy Power owner Flutter Entertainment has said it plans to raise cash to accelerate its expansion plans and bolster its finances amid coronavirus uncertainty.The group, which also owns Betfair, said it intends to secure funds through the placing of eight million shares in an equity raise.It came as the company, which completed its major merger with Stars Group earlier this month, revealed a jump in revenues for the current quarter on the back of strong online growth.Group revenues jumped % in the period from the start of April to May  as it was boosted by a % surge in revenues from Poker Stars operator Stars Group.It also reported signicant jumps in its Australia and US arms, rising % and %.The company said poker and gaming revenues grew as they ldquobenefited from strong customer engagement during the lockdown period.It said growth has started to ldquomoderate as lockdown restrictions have begun to loosen and it said it expects this trend to accelerate as more economies open up.Earlier in May, the gambling watchdog told betting firms to tighten their measures to protect problem gamblers after a surge in online gaming during the shutdown.Meanwhile, Paddy Power saw betting revenues e % as it was hit by the mass cancellation of sporting fixtures and the closure of betting shops.On Tuesday, the Government confirmed that betting shops will be among the high street firms able to reopen their doors on June ..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Paddy Power owner taps investors for cash as online gaming revenues jump

title: covid-19-testing-centre-opening-former-power-station-site
story: The drive-through centre will be operated by the st Infantry Brigade which oversees the army reserve unitsin Scotland and will carry out tests on key workers from tomorrowto Monday with plans toagain in two weeksrsquo time.East Lothian Council confirmed it had made the site available as part of the UKGovernmentrsquos Covid- testing programme.It will be the first Covid- testing site of its kind in East Lothian, where an assessment centre has also been operating at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre since the start of April.The Cockenzie site, bought by the local authority from ScottishPower, is currently being marketed for economic investment.In preparation of the appointment-only testing unitrsquos opening, signs and cones have been put in place to direct drivers.The centre will re-open on Saturday, May , through to Monday, June , and is providing back-up support to a main testing centre at EdinburghAirport.Key workers who have symptoms, or have a member of their household displaying symptoms, can self-refer to the site through the UK Governmentrsquos online portal.Military staff will make appropriate use of PPE and no equipment will be left on site while the facility is closed.The council said it expects the unit to operate as a self-contained, drivethrough facility.People will remain in their vehicle while being tested.It is not known how many tests can be carried out at the site each day.Tom Reid, the councilrsquos head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe were asked to identy a potentially suitable site for a drive-through, mobile testing facility to be located.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site was identied as a site which could be operated safely by military personnel.ldquoThis facility would enable key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms to undergo testing, which is a vital component of the national response to tackling Covid-. East Lothian Council will continue to play its part and work with partners locally and nationally in dealing with the challenges posed by the emergency.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray welcomed the move to open the centre at Cockenzie.He said: ldquoI have been calling on the Scottish Government to follow the World Health Organisationrsquos advice and ramp up the amount of testing we are doing for over a month now, so I welcome this new centre in Cockenzie and hope it will mean local key workers do not have to travel so far to access a test.ldquoA signicant increase in testing capacity will be essentialthe Scottish Governmentrsquos plans for testing, tracing and isolating are to be successful and this centre will contribute to the expansion needed.The move was also welcomed by local community councils.Bryan Hickman, chairperson of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, said: ldquoWe are pleased that the site is being used for a testing unit. It seems very suitable and hopefully it will help in getting this terrible virus under control.Brian Weddell, chairperson of Prestonpans Community Council, said: ldquoThe former power station site at Preston Links is an ideal location for a Covid testing site for East Lothian. It is remote enough from local communities with plenty of space to ensure government distancing regulations are maintained.The drive-through testing centres are available to people who live less than  minutes drive from them and are in addition to NHS Scotland testing.Scottish Government guidelines on who can apply for a test at the UK Government mobile testing centres are on their website.For a full list of those eligible to go bit.ly csBii Key workers who are, or have a family member who is, symptomatic, can sign up via the self-referral.test-for-coronavirus.service.gov.uk portal.Cockenzie power stationrsquos famous twin chimneys were demolished in a controlled explosion in September , two years after it had closed.

title: north-berwick-teen-signs-edinburgh-rugby
story: Ben Muncaster, from North Berwick, was one of three signings completed by the capital side last Friday.The back-row moves from Leicester Tigers, where he spent four years as part of the Premiership sidersquos academy.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to be joining this club.ldquoI grew up in North Berwick and have always loved Edinburgh as a city, so to be joining the professional rugby team is a dream come true.And he added: ldquoEdinburgh are obviously a very strong team with a great culture.ldquoThey have some exceptional players that I have looked up to for many years.ldquoIrsquoll hopefully try and learn from them as much as I can, certainly in the back row.ldquoIt is such an honour to have been given an opportunity like this, I am very grateful for it, and I want to make the absolute most of it.The teenager, who attended Loretto School, Musselburgh, joins Edinburgh alongside fellow Scotland age-grade players Nathan Chamberlain, who moves from Bristol Bears, and Dan Gamble, who has signed from Heriotrsquos Rugby.Richard Cockerill, head coach at Edinburgh Rugby, was pleased to sign the trio.He said: ldquoItrsquos hugely important that we continue to develop and nurture young Scottish talent, so itrsquos brilliant that wersquove been able to sign three very impressive age-grade players.ldquoBen has come through the ranks at Leicester and has consistently improved his game year after year.ldquoHe will only get better being involved and training with a talented back-row group here at Edinburgh.Muncaster has previously represented Scotland during the under-s Six Nations.Previously speaking to the Leicester Tigers website, he said: ldquoI lived near my local club when I was a kid and so itrsquos no surprise I started playing when I was about four or five.ldquoMy dad enjoys watching but never really played ndash I joined my local rugby club and loved every minute of it.

title: blow-musselburgh-racing-hopes
story: Bosses at the East Lothian track had hoped to hold races behind closed doors on Saturday, June , as the industry looks to restart under restrictions.Groundstaff at thetownrsquos award-winning
